author: Christopher Hope
title: Now Jeremy Corbyn economic adviser wants to raise £100billion by taxing the spending from your bank account
text:
Jeremy Corbyn Now Jeremy Corbyn economic adviser wants to raise £100billion by taxing the spending from your bank account Exclusive Richard Murphy, who is credited as the creator of 'Corbynomics', said the Chancellor George Osborne should start to tax people’s money as they spend it from their bank accounts Jeremy Corbyn Photo: WENN By Christopher Hope , Chief Political Correspondent 2:39PM BST 02 Oct 2015 Comments 
Britons should be levied with a new £100billion "tax on consumption" paid directly from their bank accounts, according to Jeremy Corbyn's tax adviser. 
Richard Murphy, who drafted some of Mr Corbyn's economic policies during the Labour leadership campaign , said people's money should be taxed as they spend it. 
The controversial measure is set out in Mr Murphy’s new book, called The Joy of Tax , which is published this week. 
Mr Murphy (below) says in the book that the new consumption tax could raise over £100billion a year and replace National Insurance Contributions, which disproportionately hits poorer people. 
Concerned: Tax expert Richard Murphy has reported an Isle of Man radio presenter to the police 
It says: “I think that a progressive tax on the total sum paid into and out of people’s and companies’ bank accounts is now essential. 
“This simply requires that the rate charged increase as the total payments into and out of bank accounts connected to a person increase. 
“This is the tax that can, in the 21st century, end the absurd need to tax labour and its wealth creation and instead shift that tax to excessive consumption, a shift we know is now needed.” 
He explains in the book: “It is entirely possible to tax all transactions through bank accounts that a person or company operates.” 
Mr Murphy's book "The Joy of Tax" also includes his draft of a possible Budget speech in which he brands the consumption tax as the Carbon Usage Tax. 
Speaking to The Telegraph, Mr Murphy said he would put the idea to Mr Corbyn, the Labour leader. He said this was "the next thing" after Mr Cobyn adopted his idea for people’s quantitive easing 
He said he wanted to create that tax was would “discourage people from over consuming”. 
He said: “That is contentious, that is my belief, so what I have created is the idea of what might be a variation on the financial transaction tax which is a tax on people's bank accounts.” 
Jeremy Corbyn has made a firm stand on Trident Photo: Heathcliff O'Malley/The Telegraph 
The basic rate for the Consumption Tax would start at “well under a per cent” rising to as much as 1.5 per cent as spending increases, with the tax taken monthly from the individual’s private bank account. 
This would mean that a person spending, say £20,000 a year would not pay any of the tax at all. However it would rise in bands so that someone spending £100,000 a year would pay a set amount of tax, rising to a higher band for those spending over £1million a year. 
Mr Murphy said: “If you were spending only £20,000 a year you probably pay no tax at all, if you are spending £100,000 a year you would have a tax charge. If you are spending £1million a year you would have a progressively higher tax charge. 
“What I am interested in is creating a tax system for the 21st century that builds the sort of society that we need now. 
“We have a hopelessly archaic tax called national insurance designed in 1945 which was perfect for the way we worked then and perfect for that time but which no longer meets our purposes. 
“Why doesn't it meet our purposes? It is actually a tax that discourages the creation of new employment.” 
Photo: Heathcliff O'Malley/The Telegraph 
George Osborne, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, has previously signalled that he wants to merge income tax with National Insurance . 
Mr Murphy is one of the co-founders of the Tax Justice Network, the campaigning organisation that has been at the forefront of the battle to bring the iniquities of tax havens into the spotlight. 
His idea for “people’s QE” was picked up by Mr Corbyn as a variant on the Government’s £375bn quantitative easing programme to unblock the credit markets in the depths of recession. 
It would see the Bank of England printing money to invest in public infrastructure projects, at the same time as boosting employment and economic growth.
